title: Riot, I really used to like your IP cost reduction on champion prices
body:
How the cost for older champions would go down every time a new champ was released

But this was only introduced when you made the move from a new champ every 2 weeks to a new champ every 3 months.

REALLY OLD champs like Rammus, Anivia, Kassadin and even Olaf are still 3150 IP.  Galio is 4800.  GALIO

Every champ after Ziggs, who was released over 3 years ago (Feb 1st 2012), costs 6300 IP.

IMO, your price reduction should go from every champ release to once every Month. Instead of when a new champ is released, the oldest 6300 IP champ goes to 4800 IP, and every 3rd release a 4800 IP champ goes to a random lower bracket, it should look like this;

Every month, the oldest 6300 champ is dropped to 4800 IP, the oldest 4800 champ is dropped to 3150 IP, the oldest 3150 champ is dropped to 1350 IP.  Every 3 months, the oldest 1350 champ is dropped to 450 IP.

This way, people who are new to the game or who don't play 24/7 can still build a champion pool without farming forever.  Between this and trying to get runes and rune pages, its ridiculous.

TL;DR Champion IP prices should be dropping more frequently

I think my issue is that your rule isn't sustainable. It's actually *too* fast, and will quickly lead to a pile of 450 champs, along with one of each higher bracket.

Also, keep in mind that many prices remain high because of the expected difficulty/complexity of the champion. They're high specifically to discourage newer players from trying them before they've got a solid grasp of the basics, and I find it hard to argue with that concept.

That said, I don't generally disagree with you. I'd certainly like to see more prices come down more often. But I don't know how to manage it at a sustainable rate beyond using champ releases as a base measurement.

Have an intended price tier for each champ:

"This is Azir. He's a very mechanically complex champ, so we think he should remain higher-priced. He'll be released at 7800 and be reduced by 300 IP per month until he reaches 4800, where he'll stay."

While I do somewhat agree that the price reductions were a good idea, I also understand why some of the prices are high to begin with. If you had Annie and Zed both at 450 IP, you'd have a lot more new players (genuine new players, not the smurfs) who run into an extremely complex champion when they barely have the most basic grasp of the game and its mechanics. Then when you do consider the smurfs that actually do know how to take advantage of the champ, they have an even easier way to roflstomp genuinely new players and make them feel bad for ever trying the game.

Additionally, with the cadence of champ releases slowing significantly, having price reductions at the proposed rate makes it incredibly easy to collect all the champs with little effort which decreases the incentive to buy them with RP (it's still a business). It's already been over 2 years since a champ was released with me not having enough IP to instabuy them and for a solid few of them that was at a 7800 price point. I recently got tired of having so much IP so I bought up every rune I could ever conceivably use (meaning everything except things like AP/lvl Marks or Energy Regen Quints). I'm still currently sitting on over 8k and I have no idea what I can do with it because it will likely be over 15k by the time the next champ releases and that's the biggest factor. With fewer champs coming out in longer periods of time, there's more time to farm IP and catch up.

Besides, if you're still lacking in runes, that's what you should be focusing on, not champ collection. That and getting better with the champs you have.

The average 30m game gives you 55 IP if you factor in win vs lose, so to unlock a 6300 champion, it would take you 57 hours of in-game time.  This doesn't include time wasted in queue, in lobby, or when games get reset due to AFKs or denials.  This also doesn't include Win of the Day bonus, which is roughly 150 IP every 24 hours.  To ball park it, most people are capable of unlocking 1x 6300 champion a month with fairly dedicated gameplay.

The problem is, we haven't accounted for runes, rune pages, or an opening champion pool (aside from luxury picks).  How much of Riot's player base plays LoL more than 20 hours a week? That's the only way new players would have a remote chance to unlock their needed content to play ranked effectively in a single season.  Most people don't want a hopeless grind, nor have the time to do so.  I suppose that's the entire point, to force people into buying RP for things other games give for free (i.e. DOTA2).

In fact, I had 3 friends that I convinced to start up LoL in the last year that all got to around level 15 before they gave up on the pointless grind that is IP and XP gains.  Speaking as a player who started LoL in Season 1, back in 2010, I hit level 30 in a single month, and earned enough IP to buy everything in the game in 6 months.  Players starting now would be lucky to hit level 30 in 6 months, and have absolutely no hopes of unlocking just half the game's champions in 2 full years.  That is simply absurd.
